page.title: 02Hartley Pans (continued)
page.content: were placed at Flodden to stop salt from going over the border into Scotland. This did the salt trade a lot of harm and was the beginning for a black market in salt. Salt continued to be produced for a few more years but this was all used in the Glass Houses. The pans were finally closed down in 1820 and no traces of them remain. They were situated on the right bank of the river, East of the main road bridge and the salt drying houses were on Rocky Island which was known then as the{"Pans Close." W. Coulson. Undoubtedly the most famous pit sinker of hos day, William Coulson had, at the time of the disaster been 48 years in the work and had sunk 84 pits including that of Hartley. His skilled work gained him praise and abuse.
